title: I’m 14. I want to start taking vocal lessons and want to sing as a career, but my parents won’t let me. Music has become a big part of me this past year. What should I do? - Quora

response.answer_text: You should find out from your parents why they are unwilling or unable to allow you to take voice lessons. It might be that they can’t afford them—mine cost $120/month, and the only reason I’m able to pay for them is because I got a raise at work. It might be Covid. Singing is a good way to spread the virus because you are forcing air out of your lungs for extended breaths, rather than for short breaths as you do when speaking. Maybe transportation is a problem. They might be unable to transport you to or from the lessons. Are you already in choir, and they don’t want to have to take you to and from two extracurricular things? Are your grades satisfactory? That would be another reason for them to possibly turn you down. Luckily for you, there is Youtube—but be careful. Consult with the choir director at your school or with a voice teacher you trust, and ask that person which Youtube voice instructors you should learn from. This way, you can at least start learning vocal exercises. Youtube is not ideal. Ideal is having a voice teacher who can touch your abdomen and tell you if you’re supporting your breath correctly. I learned more in one lesson from a teacher who asked permission to touch my abdomen and gave me feedback than I did from five years of studying with a teacher who didn’t touch me. It may be that your parents want to see some dedication from you to this goal, rather than shelling out money for you to take lessons for what they might consider a lark. I have no idea. Your best bet is to get an understanding of what your parents’ objection is to voice lessons, and work from there. Good luck!

Prove to them that you are able to accomplish your dream while studying since you are quite young, maybe start by creating a YouTube channel start making cover and get really good grades so they could see it’s not affecting you academically, once they see that they’ll be able to let loose a little and try to make good quality videos to get more views and show them it’s not hopeless, maybe do singing a (popular trending song) in public, anything that’ll help you gain a few more views maybe do a video singing bts dynamite in public with a cool thumbnail, that’ll get you a good amount of views, once they see that you are succeeding in both they’ll help you achieve your dreams. for the vocal lessons maybe start training yourself and be good enough to sing on YouTube sing not so vocally hard songs, so you can master them, and perhaps start busking or working and pay for your own vocal lessons. just show them that you are determined enough to pursue this as a career, they won’t let you do it unless you put in the work needed in order to achieve that.
